title: Meta's Mixed Reality Shake-up: What It Means for Developers
description: In this episode, we dive into Meta's recent pivot in its spending for VR and AR apps on Quest headsets, and how this shift has impacted developers, market trends, and the future of the mixed reality space.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial,' where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're looking into a big shift in the world of virtual reality. Specifically, how Meta Platforms, formerly known as Facebook, is rethinking its approach to spending on apps and content for its Quest headsets. This news comes from a recent report by *The Information*, titled 'Meta’s VR App Funding Retreat Forces Developers to Slash Staff.'

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Over the past few years, Meta has poured millions into developing apps and content to support its Quest headsets, part of its push into virtual and augmented reality, or what the company calls 'mixed reality.' However, it appears that Meta is becoming more selective with how it invests in apps for these platforms. With sales in the mixed reality space weakening, Meta is now focusing on specific genres that they believe will have broader appeal.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Meta’s new approach has already started to impact developers. According to the report, the company has closed one of its own internal VR studios and reduced funding for certain external app developers. This shift has led to significant changes for many studios and developers who were previously working on Meta's projects.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One example of the impact is with Monks, a Dutch company that had been building virtual worlds for Meta’s Horizon Worlds app. Since Meta suspended funding, Monks had to cut their team working on VR and mixed reality projects by half. Similarly, a Paris-based startup called Atlas V, which developed popular VR titles like 'Wallace & Gromit in The Grand Getaway,' also had to reduce its workforce significantly after Meta scaled back its funding for new projects.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what is Meta’s new focus? Well, they are prioritizing lifestyle apps—think fashion, beauty, and music—as well as games with broader appeal. They’re even supporting these initiatives through a seed-stage funding accelerator program for Quest app developers.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Interestingly, Meta is also adjusting its pricing strategy on the hardware side. The Quest 3S, Meta's latest headset, has seen a price reduction to $299.99. It’s clear that Meta is trying to make the hardware more accessible as a way to grow its user base, especially with the recent entrance of Apple into the mixed reality space with its high-end Vision Pro.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Despite these moves, it’s not all about VR for Meta. The company is also doubling down on artificial intelligence, even as its Reality Labs division faces budget cuts and spending reductions for hardware development. Meta’s AI focus could suggest a pivot in their long-term vision—potentially toward experiences that extend beyond VR headsets.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And while Meta has committed to increasing developer funding overall this year compared to last, the reallocation of those funds has still created frustrations among developers. Several developers have mentioned that the changes in Meta’s funding priorities made it harder for smaller apps to get noticed, especially after Meta merged the Quest App Lab, which was meant for smaller, experimental apps, with the Quest Store, which hosts larger, high-profile games.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Meta’s leadership, including CTO Andrew Bosworth and others, has acknowledged these concerns. Bosworth even apologized at Meta’s Connect developer conference, acknowledging that developing for Meta’s platforms has not always been easy and that they are actively working to address these challenges.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In another strategic move, Meta has also pulled back on developing high-end XR headsets and has instead greenlit a new XR glasses-like device. This shift toward more discreet, wearable tech—smart glasses rather than headsets—could align with trends toward AI integration and more seamless user experiences. But for now, this strategy doesn’t create many opportunities for outside developers since Meta’s Ray-Ban smart glasses lack an app store or display function to support third-party content.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Looking forward, it’s clear that Meta has a balancing act to manage here. They need to keep VR developers engaged to create compelling content for the Quest platform. Without quality content, there’s less incentive for consumers to buy and use VR devices. But on the other hand, Meta needs to ensure that the apps they fund have the potential for widespread appeal, especially as competition in the XR space grows more intense.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Ultimately, Meta's mixed reality journey highlights some of the broader challenges facing the VR and AR industries. Market trends show a decline in XR device sales overall, but mixed reality devices—those that blend the physical and digital worlds—have shown some growth. As companies like Meta, Apple, and others continue to evolve in this space, the path forward remains uncertain but certainly intriguing.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Thanks for tuning in to 'Life is Artificial.' For more on Meta’s VR funding changes, you can check out the full article from *The Information*, linked in our show notes. Until next time, stay curious and keep exploring the future of technology.
